title: 111_s2882
content: The Act may be cited as the "Taxpayer Responsibility, Accountability, and Consistency Act of 2009". It includes an expansion of information reporting requirements. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include corporations in the definition of 'person' for reporting purposes. The Secretary is authorized to issue regulations to prevent duplicate reporting of transactions. Additionally, subsection (a) of section 6041 is amended to include payments for property and other gross proceeds. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include corporations in the definition of 'person' for reporting purposes. The Secretary is authorized to issue regulations to prevent duplicate reporting of transactions. Amendments made by this section apply to payments made after December 31, 2011, including inserting "gross proceeds" in specified sections. SEC. 3. DETERMINATION OF ELIGIBILITY FOR SAFE HARBOR TREATMENT OF INDIVIDUALS AS NON-EMPLOYEES FOR EMPLOYMENT TAXES. (a) In General.--Chapter 25 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by adding a new section: "SEC. 3511. SAFE HARBOR." The text discusses the termination of certain employment tax liability if a taxpayer did not treat an individual as an employee for a period and filed all required federal tax returns consistently with that treatment. The individual will not be deemed an employee for tax purposes unless the taxpayer lacked a reasonable basis for not treating them as an employee. The text outlines conditions under which an individual is not considered an employee for tax purposes, provided the taxpayer had a reasonable basis for this classification, such as a written determination on employment status. The text outlines conditions for an individual not considered an employee for tax purposes if there was a concluded examination on their employment status with no determination made, and if no other individual in a similar position has been treated as an employee for employment taxes since December 31, 1977. The text defines employment tax as any tax imposed by this subtitle and employment status as the status of an individual as an employee or independent contractor. Special rules require the IRS to provide written notice before examining an individual's employment status. The text outlines rules for taxpayers regarding reliance on examinations or written determinations of employment status, specifying that reliance is not allowed if facts have changed or were misrepresented by the taxpayer, or if the Secretary issues contrary guidance. The text outlines rules for taxpayers regarding reliance on examinations or written determinations of employment status. A taxpayer must establish entitlement to relief under this section by a preponderance of the evidence. Individuals performing services for a taxpayer may petition for a determination of their status for employment tax purposes. The procedures for determining an individual's employment tax status include a 90-day deadline for industries with transient, casual, or seasonal employment. Taxpayers can appeal determinations and the Secretary must seek information from the individual when requested. The Secretary must seek information from individuals regarding their performance of services for the taxpayer and provide written notice of their employment tax status determination. If misclassification is found, the Secretary will notify the Secretary of Labor and the individual about eligibility for self-employment tax refunds. Regulations must be prescribed within one year to carry out the purposes of this section. Regulations will be prescribed to carry out the purposes of this section, with conforming amendments to the Internal Revenue Code. Section 3511 establishes a safe harbor provision. Section 530 of the Revenue Act of 1978 will no longer apply to services rendered more than 1 year after the enactment of this Act. The amendments made by this section will apply to services rendered more than 1 year after the enactment of this Act. Additionally, there will be annual reports on worker misclassification. The Secretary of the Treasury will issue an annual report on worker misclassification, including enforcement actions, relief obtained, estimates of misclassified employers and affected workers, impact on the tax system, and outcomes of petitions filed under section 3511(e) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Additionally, there will be an increase in information return penalties. The penalties for failure to file correct information returns under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 have been increased. The penalty amounts have been raised from $50 to $250, and from $250,000 to $3,000,000. Additionally, there are reduced penalties for corrections made within specified timeframes. Section 6721(b)(2) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to increase penalties from $30 to $100, $50 to $250, and $150,000 to $1,500,000. Section 6721(d)(1) is also amended to lower penalties for persons with gross receipts of not more than $5,000,000, with changes from $100,000 to $1,000,000, $250,000 to $3,000,000, and $25,000 to $175,000. In summary, penalties for non-compliance with the Internal Revenue Code have been increased significantly. For example, penalties for intentional disregard have been raised from $100 to $500, and from $250,000 to $3,000,000. Additionally, penalties for failure to furnish correct payee statements have been increased from $50 to $250. The penalties for non-compliance with the Internal Revenue Code have been increased significantly. For instance, penalties for intentional disregard have been raised to $500 from $100, and to $1,000,000 from $250,000. Penalties for failure to comply with other information reporting requirements have also been increased to $250 from $50, and to $1,000,000 from $100,000. These amendments apply to information returns due after December 31, 2009.
